abstract.p: Slew of Canadian bands from Montreal and Toronto have caught fire in United States; photos (M)

block.p: What happens in Canada tends to stay in Canada. Except when it comes to music. Recently, a slew of bands from Montreal and Toronto have caught fire in the United States, which suggests a trek north of the border for an authentic music-heavy weekend. Remember, the dollar is strong, and they can cuss in English.

MONTREAL Bands: the Arcade Fire (above), for poignant pop-rock; the Dears, for melancholy orchestral arrangements with a touch of noir; the Stills, for songs with a New Romantic twist. Venues: Cafe Campus (57 Prince Arthur East; 514-844-1010). Club Metropolis (59 Rue St. Catherine East; for tickets, call 514-908-9090). Bar: Le Pistol (3723 Boulevard St. Laurent; 514-847-2222). Good for late-night pub fare, foosball and local-musician sightings. Restaurants: Casa del Popolo (4873 Boulevard St. Laurent; 514-284-3804) is a popular band hangout. La Sala Rossa (4848 Boulevard St. Laurent; 514-844-4227) is another musicians' favorite. Fameux Viande Fumée et Charcuterie (4500 Saint-Denis; 514-845-8732) dishes up Montreal's best poutine (a mix of fries, cheese curd and gravy). Toqué (900 Place Jean-Paul-Riopelle; 514-499-2084) serves Normand Laprise's high-end cuisine. Where to stay: the boutique-y W Montreal, at far right (901 Victoria Square; 514-395-3100). Record store: CD Esoterik (1841 Rue St. Catherine West; 514-937-5192). Bonus: the Pop Montreal festival (Sept. 28 through Oct. 2; go to www.popmontreal.com).

TORONTO Bands: Metric approaches melody the new-wave way; the rapper k-os (above right) bridges reggae, old-school hip-hop and R & B; for atmosphere, check out Broken Social Scene, the city's 10-plus-member post-rock collective. Venues: Lee's Palace (529 Bloor Street West; 416-532-1598). The Horseshoe Tavern (370 Queen Street West; 416-598-4753). Bar: Communist's Daughter (1149 Dundas Street West; 647-435-0103). A stellar jukebox and great pickled eggs. Restaurants: Susur (601 King Street West; 416-603-2205) and Lee (603 King Street West; 416-504-7867) both serve the critically acclaimed fare of Susur Lee, a Hong Kong chef. Where to stay: Drake Hotel (1150 Queen Street West; 416-531-5042). In a burgeoning gallery district, it was recently redone and has a minimally designed bar, restaurant and performance space that attracts hockey fans. Hôtel Le Germain (30 Mercer Street; 416-345-9500) embodies casual chic. Record store: Rotate This (620 Queen Street West; 416-504-8447). Bonus: the North by Northeast Music and Film Festival (June 9 through 11; go to www.nxne.com).
